data.question: Which of the following ports listed below are designated ports following STP convergence?
data.correct_answer: Fa0/1 on switch A AND Fa0/2 on switch A
data.incorrect_answers__001: Fa0/2 on switch A AND Fa0/1 on switch C
data.incorrect_answers__002:
Fa0/1 on switch C AND Fa0/1 on switch A
Fa0/2 on switch A AND Fa0/1 on switch C
data.incorrect_answers__003: Fa0/1 on switch B AND Fa0/2 on switch A
data.explanation:
The following ports are designated ports:
	• Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch A are designated ports. Switch A is the root bridge. All ports on the root bridge are designated ports.
	• Fa0/2 on switch B is also a designated port. There must be one designated port per segment. The port on switch B is used because the MAC address for switch B is lower than the MAC address on switch C.
Fa0/1 on switch B and Fa0/1 on switch C are root ports. The root port is the port with the lowest cost back to the root bridge.
data.incorrect_answers:
['Fa0/2 on switch A AND Fa0/1 on switch C','Fa0/1 on switch C AND Fa0/1 on switch A
Fa0/2 on switch A AND Fa0/1 on switch C','Fa0/1 on switch B AND Fa0/2 on switch A']
data.answer1: Fa0/1 on switch A AND Fa0/2 on switch A
data.answer2: Fa0/2 on switch A AND Fa0/1 on switch C
data.answer3:
Fa0/1 on switch C AND Fa0/1 on switch A
Fa0/2 on switch A AND Fa0/1 on switch C
data.answer4: Fa0/1 on switch B AND Fa0/2 on switch A

data.question: Which switch becomes the root bridge?
data.correct_answer: D
data.incorrect_answers__001: A
data.explanation: Switch D is the root bridge because its priority value is the lowest. If the priority values were the same, then the switch with the lowest MAC address would be the root bridge.
data.answer1: D
data.answer2: A

data.question: Which of the following best describes OSPF?
data.correct_answer: OSPF is a classless link-state routing protocol.
data.incorrect_answers__001: OSPF is a classless distance vector routing protocol.
data.incorrect_answers__002: OSPF is a classful link-state routing protocol.
data.incorrect_answers__003: OSPF is a classful distance vector routing protocol.
data.explanation:
OSPF is a classless link-state routing protocol.
RIP version 1 and IGRP are both classful distance vector routing protocols. EIGRP is a hybrid protocol that supports classless addressing.
data.incorrect_answers: ['OSPF is a classless distance vector routing protocol.','OSPF is a classful link-state routing protocol.','OSPF is a classful distance vector routing protocol.']
data.answer1: OSPF is a classless link-state routing protocol.
data.answer2: OSPF is a classless distance vector routing protocol.
data.answer3: OSPF is a classful link-state routing protocol.
data.answer4: OSPF is a classful distance vector routing protocol.

data.question:
OSPF is a classless link-state routing protocol.
RIP version 1 and IGRP are both classful distance vector routing protocols. EIGRP is a hybrid protocol that supports classless addressing.
How are routing tables created by link-state routing protocols?
data.correct_answer: The SPF algorithm is applied to the topological database to create a routing table.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Replacement routing tables are periodically received from the Designated Border Router.
data.incorrect_answers__002: Routing tables are received from neighbor routers and consolidated into the local router.
data.incorrect_answers__003: The administrator initially configures each route, then they are exchanged with neighbor routers.
data.explanation:
Link-state routing protocols build their routing tables by applying the Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm to the topological database. They do not exchange routing tables with neighbor routers
By default, the Designated Border Router sends update entries only to each router not the entire routing table. Although statically configured routes can coexist with a dynamic routing protocol, they are not required with link-state routing protocols.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Replacement routing tables are periodically received from the Designated Border Router.','Routing tables are received from neighbor routers and consolidated into the local router.','The administrator initially configures each route, then they are exchanged with neighbor routers.']
data.answer1: The SPF algorithm is applied to the topological database to create a routing table.
data.answer2: Replacement routing tables are periodically received from the Designated Border Router.
data.answer3: Routing tables are received from neighbor routers and consolidated into the local router.
data.answer4: The administrator initially configures each route, then they are exchanged with neighbor routers.

data.question: How do link-state routing protocols determine the topology of the network?
data.correct_answer: Each router initially exchanges LSP messages which are used to build a topological database.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Redundant paths are built between routers for fault tolerance.
data.incorrect_answers__002: The administrator plans the hierarchical design then statically configures each routing entry.
data.incorrect_answers__003: The Spanning Tree protocol is enabled by default to prevent looping.
data.explanation:
With link-state protocols, each router initially exchanges a 'hello' packet, also called a Link-State Packet (LSP), with all the other routers in the network. The collection of LSPs are used to build a topological database
Although statically configured routes can coexist with a dynamic routing protocol, they are not required with link-state routing protocols. Link-state routing protocols do not build redundancy. The Spanning Tree protocol is used to prevent looping in switching, not in routing.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Redundant paths are built between routers for fault tolerance.','The administrator plans the hierarchical design then statically configures each routing entry.','The Spanning Tree protocol is enabled by default to prevent looping.']
data.answer1: Each router initially exchanges LSP messages which are used to build a topological database.
data.answer2: Redundant paths are built between routers for fault tolerance.
data.answer3: The administrator plans the hierarchical design then statically configures each routing entry.
data.answer4: The Spanning Tree protocol is enabled by default to prevent looping.

data.question: What are the common elements of a network hierarchy used by link-state routing protocols?
data.correct_answer: Area AND Autonomous System
data.incorrect_answers__001: Designated Port AND Bridgehead
data.explanation:
Bridgehead AND Autonomous System
Link-state routing uses areas and an Autonomous System (AS) to subdivide the network. An area is a grouping of networks which logically subdivide the AS. The AS is a collection of areas under a common administration.
The Root Bridge and Designated Port are elements of the Spanning Tree Protocol used in a switched network.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Designated Port AND Bridgehead','Root Bridge AND Bridgehead','Bridgehead AND Autonomous System']
data.answer1: Area AND Autonomous System
data.answer2: Designated Port AND Bridgehead

data.question: Which of the following are true about the link-state routing method?
data.correct_answer: Convergence is faster than with the distance vector method.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Routers share their entire routing tables at each reporting interval.
data.incorrect_answers__002: Compiling routing table information and computing routes is a relatively simple process.
data.incorrect_answers__003:
Compiling routing table information and computing routes is a relatively simple process.
Link state routers are susceptible to routing loops.
data.explanation:
Link state routers send updates immediately as they happen. For this reason, convergence happens faster than with the distance vector method.
Link state routers share only first-hand information. This reduces the amount of network traffic that results from sharing routing information.
Link state routers perform a complex algorithm to compile network data and calculate routes. For this reason, link state routers often have higher hardware and software requirements.
data.incorrect_answers:
['Routers share their entire routing tables at each reporting interval.','Compiling routing table information and computing routes is a relatively simple process.','Compiling routing table information and computing routes is a relatively simple process.
Link state routers are susceptible to routing loops.']
data.answer1: Convergence is faster than with the distance vector method.
data.answer2: Routers share their entire routing tables at each reporting interval.
data.answer3: Compiling routing table information and computing routes is a relatively simple process.
data.answer4:
Compiling routing table information and computing routes is a relatively simple process.
Link state routers are susceptible to routing loops.

data.question:
You implemented a trunking configuration between two switches. On switch A, you have used the show interface fa 0/1 trunk command and received the output as shown in the exhibit.
If the other switch has default configurations, which of the following is true?
data.correct_answer: Traffic on the native VLAN will not be transmitted correctly. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.
data.incorrect_answers__001: VLAN 5 has not been configured on the switch. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.
data.incorrect_answers__002: Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A. and VLAN 5 has not been configured on the switch.
data.incorrect_answers__003: FastEthernet 0/1 is configured to trunk unconditionally. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.
data.explanation:
The default native VLAN is 1. Line 1 indicates that the native VLAN of switch A is 2. If the native VLAN on one end of the trunk is different than the native VLAN on the other end, the traffic of the native VLANs on both sides cannot be transmitted correctly on the trunk.
Line 4 indicates which VLANs are allowed to communicate over the trunk. VLAN 5 is not permitted to communicate over the trunk. To specify that a VLAN is not permitted to communicate over a trunk interface, use the switchport trunk allowed vlan remove <vlan id> command.
If all VLANs were permitted to communicate over the trunk, the output would state 1-4094.
Line 1 indicates that the trunking mode is dynamic desirable. If the FastEthernet 0/1 was configured to trunk unconditionally, the output would state on as the mode.
data.incorrect_answers: ['VLAN 5 has not been configured on the switch. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.','Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A. and VLAN 5 has not been configured on the switch.','FastEthernet 0/1 is configured to trunk unconditionally. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.']
data.answer1: Traffic on the native VLAN will not be transmitted correctly. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.
data.answer2: VLAN 5 has not been configured on the switch. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.
data.answer3: Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A. and VLAN 5 has not been configured on the switch.
data.answer4: FastEthernet 0/1 is configured to trunk unconditionally. and Traffic from VLAN 5 will not be forwarded from switch A.

data.question: You have a Layer 3 switch that is capable of interVLAN routing. What process must you complete to allow interVLAN routing on a Layer 3 switch interface?
data.correct_answer: Configure the interface as a switch virtual interface
data.incorrect_answers__001: Implement a three-tier network design with access-layer, distribution-layer, and core-layer switches
data.incorrect_answers__002: Configure spanning tree protocol (STP) to prevent interVLAN looping
data.incorrect_answers__003: Configure link-state routing, such as OSPF or EIGRP
data.explanation:
To allow interVLAN routing, the multilayer switch interface must be configured as a switch virtual interface (SVI).
No specific routing protocol, such as OSPF or EIGRP, is required to allow interVLAN routing on a multilayer switch. STP is not required to allow routing on a multilayer switch, either. The three-tier network design is not required to allow routing on a multilayer switch, but an SVI is usually implemented to interconnect the VLANs between distribution-layer and access-layer switches in a multi-switch network.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Implement a three-tier network design with access-layer, distribution-layer, and core-layer switches','Configure spanning tree protocol (STP) to prevent interVLAN looping','Configure link-state routing, such as OSPF or EIGRP']
data.answer1: Configure the interface as a switch virtual interface
data.answer2: Implement a three-tier network design with access-layer, distribution-layer, and core-layer switches
data.answer3: Configure spanning tree protocol (STP) to prevent interVLAN looping
data.answer4: Configure link-state routing, such as OSPF or EIGRP

data.question: What happens when an HSRP active router fails?
data.correct_answer: The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.incorrect_answers__001:
The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message.  AND The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. 
The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.incorrect_answers__002: The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.incorrect_answers__003:
The virtual IP address is cleared from the virtual router's ARP cache and repopulated with the standby router's virtual IP address. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.explanation:
The active router assumes and maintains its role through the use of hello messages. When the active router fails, the other HSRP routers stop receiving the hello messages. The standby router assumes the role of active router when the holdtime expires. The holdtime is the time between the receipt of a hello message and the presumption that the sending router has failed.
Additional HSRP member routers remain in the listen state, participating only if the holdtime expires.
The original active router may regain service after a failure, but depending on preemption, may not regain the active router HSRP group state.
data.incorrect_answers:
['The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message.  AND The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. 
The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.','The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.','The virtual IP address is cleared from the virtual router's ARP cache and repopulated with the standby router's virtual IP address. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.']
data.answer1: The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.answer2:
The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message.  AND The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. 
The HSRP standby router becomes the active router after the holdtime expires on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.answer3: The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
data.answer4:
The virtual IP address is cleared from the virtual router's ARP cache and repopulated with the standby router's virtual IP address. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.
The active router will return to service within the holdtime amount on the hello message. AND Additional HSRP member routers transition from the listen state after the holdtime expires on the hello message.

data.question:
Which IPv6 ACL types match with these descriptions of their usage:
Filters inbound and outbound traffic
Applies only to packets that are routed
Filters traffic on Layer 3 interfaces
data.correct_answer: Router ACL
data.incorrect_answers__001: Port ACL
data.explanation:
The two types of IPv6 ACLs are used as follows:
• Router ACLs filter inbound and outbound traffic on Layer 3 interfaces (e.g., routed ports, SVIs, etc.). Router ACLs are applied only to packets that are routed.
Port ACLs filter inbound traffic on Layer 2 interfaces. Port ACLs are applied to all packets, therefore taking precedence.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Port ACL',' ',' ']
data.answer1: Router ACL
data.answer2: Port ACL

data.question: Which of the following is a good general rule regarding the placement of extended ACLs?
data.correct_answer: Extended ACLs should be placed as close as possible to the source router.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Extended ACLs should be placed on access-layer routers.
data.incorrect_answers__002: Extended ACLs should be placed on the default gateway router.
data.incorrect_answers__003: Extended ACLs should be placed on distribution-layer routers.
data.explanation:
As a general rule, extended access lists should be placed as close as possible to the source router. Then packets are not sent throughout the rest of the network.
Standard ACLs should be placed as close as possible to the destination.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Extended ACLs should be placed on access-layer routers.','Extended ACLs should be placed on the default gateway router.','Extended ACLs should be placed on distribution-layer routers.','Extended ACLs should be placed as close as possible to the destination router.']
data.answer1: Extended ACLs should be placed as close as possible to the source router.
data.answer2: Extended ACLs should be placed on access-layer routers.
data.answer3: Extended ACLs should be placed on the default gateway router.
data.answer4: Extended ACLs should be placed on distribution-layer routers.
data.answer5: Extended ACLs should be placed as close as possible to the destination router.

data.question: Your company has two subnets, 172.16.1.0 and 172.16.2.0 as shown in the exhibit. Recent policy changes forbid FTP traffic from leaving your company; however, all other traffic is allowed. You've created the following access list to meet the new company requirements: access-list 101 deny tcp any any eq 20 access-list 101 deny tcp any any eq 21 access-list 101 permit ip any any Where should you apply this filter?
data.correct_answer: outbound side of S0
data.incorrect_answers__001:
inbound side of E0
outbound side of S0
data.explanation:
inbound side of E1
You must apply the ACL to the outbound side of S0. This will prevent FTP traffic from leaving the S0 interface (while allowing it through all other interfaces as well as to enter the S0 interface).
If you apply the ACL to the inbound side of S0, you would only block FTP traffic entering your company network, not leaving it.
If you apply the ACL to any interface other than S0, by default FTP traffic will be permitted out of your company.
data.incorrect_answers:
['inbound side of E0
outbound side of S0','outbound side of E0','inbound side of E1']
data.answer1: outbound side of S0
data.answer2:
inbound side of E0
outbound side of S0

data.question:
You have entered the following command to enable dynamic trunking configuration:
Switch(config-if)#switchport mode dynamic desirable
If the switch interface is connected to another switch, what will it attempt to do?
data.correct_answer: Negotiate a link using the desired trunking protocol
data.incorrect_answers__001:
Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using trunk mode
Negotiate a link using the desired trunking protocol
data.incorrect_answers__002: Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using dynamic auto mode
data.incorrect_answers__003: Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using dynamic desirable mode
data.explanation:
Dynamic trunking configuration is enabled on a switch interface using the following command:
Switch(config-if)#switchport mode dynamic desirable
If the switch interface is connected to another switch, it will attempt to negotiate a trunk link to that switch using the desired trunking protocol. It will successfully negotiate a trunk link if the connected switch is using either dynamic auto, dynamic desirable, or trunk mode.
If the connected switch is using access mode, a trunk link cannot be negotiated, and it will communicate as a normal port.
data.incorrect_answers:
['Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using trunk mode
Negotiate a link using the desired trunking protocol','Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using dynamic auto mode','Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using dynamic desirable mode']
data.answer1: Negotiate a link using the desired trunking protocol
data.answer2:
Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using trunk mode
Negotiate a link using the desired trunking protocol
data.answer3: Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using dynamic auto mode
data.answer4: Negotiate a link only with a switch that is using dynamic desirable mode

Switch(config-if)#switchport mode dynamic desirable

data.question: You have just connected four switches as shown in the image. Assuming the default switch configuration, which switch will become the root bridge?
data.correct_answer: B
data.incorrect_answers__001: A
data.explanation: The switch with the lowest bridge ID becomes the root bridge. The bridge ID is composed of two parts: a bridge priority number and the MAC address assigned to the switch. The default priority number for all switches is 32,768. This means that for unconfigured switches, the switch with the lowest MAC address becomes the root bridge. In this example, bridge B has the lowest MAC address.
data.answer1: B
data.answer2: A

data.question: Which statements accurately describe port states of both bridges and switches?
data.correct_answer: In the learning state, the MAC address table can be populated but frames are not forwarded. AND Ports in a blocked state still receive BPDUs.
data.incorrect_answers__001: In the learning state, the MAC address table cannot be populated because the port is blocked. AND Ports in a blocked state still receive BPDUs.

data.incorrect_answers__003: In the learning state, the MAC address table cannot be populated because the port is blocked. AND Ports in a blocked state cannot receive BPDUs.

For both bridges and switches:
	• In the learning state, ports do not forward frames but still populate the MAC address table based on frames received. 
	• In the blocking state, ports receive BPDUs but do not forward frames. 
In the listening state, all ports are blocked.

data.question: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of using the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) in network segmented bridges?
data.correct_answer: STP minimizes the convergence time required for bridges to share network information.
data.incorrect_answers__001: STP identifies the most efficient path through a bridged network.
data.incorrect_answers__002: STP prevents message loops from forming.
data.incorrect_answers__003: STP lets you provide redundancy by using more than one connection between devices, which makes your network more stable.
data.explanation:
STP lets you provide redundancy by using more than one connection between devices, which makes your network more stable.
The Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) prevents loops in a bridged network. It allows multiple paths to exist between two devices in case of network failure. The Spanning Tree Protocol is the method bridges use to configure the best path through the network. However, each bridge does not maintain a map of the network. Instead, it simply identifies which port should be used to forward packets. When a bridge starts up, the Spanning Tree Protocol is run to identify the best port. Because each bridge is configured to select the optimal port, the best path through the network is identified.
data.incorrect_answers: ['STP identifies the most efficient path through a bridged network.','STP prevents message loops from forming.','STP lets you provide redundancy by using more than one connection between devices, which makes your network more stable.']
data.answer1: STP minimizes the convergence time required for bridges to share network information.
data.answer2: STP identifies the most efficient path through a bridged network.
data.answer3: STP prevents message loops from forming.
data.answer4: STP lets you provide redundancy by using more than one connection between devices, which makes your network more stable.

data.question: You have three switches configured as shown in the image. How could you guarantee that switch C becomes the root bridge?
data.correct_answer: Configure switch C with a lower priority value.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a higher cost value.
data.incorrect_answers__002: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a lower port priority.
data.incorrect_answers__003: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a higher port priority.
data.explanation:
To guarantee that switch C becomes the root bridge, configure switch C with a lower priority value. The election of the root bridge is determined by the switch with the lowest bridge ID. The bridge ID is made of two parts:
	• The priority value assigned to the switch.
	• The MAC address.
The switch with the lowest priority value automatically becomes the root bridge. If two or more switches have the same priority value, then the switch with the lowest MAC address becomes the root bridge.
The link cost is used when determining the root port and the designated ports, with the path with the lowest cost is used. The port priority is used only when there are two equal-cost paths back to the root bridge on the same switch. The port with the lower priority is used. If two ports have the same priority, the port with the lowest port number is used.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a higher cost value.','Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a lower port priority.','Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a higher port priority.','Configure switch C with a higher priority value.']
data.answer1: Configure switch C with a lower priority value.
data.answer2: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a higher cost value.
data.answer3: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a lower port priority.
data.answer4: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a higher port priority.
data.answer5: Configure switch C with a higher priority value.
data.answer6: Configure Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 on switch C with a lower cost value.

data.question: What problem does the Spanning Tree Protocol prevent?
data.correct_answer: It prevents message loops from developing when a switch or bridge is connected to the same location more than once.
data.incorrect_answers__001: It doesn't prevent any problem. Instead, it creates an overall routing table (a span tree) for the entire network.
data.incorrect_answers__002: It prevents buffer overflows by defining source-quench messages that a receiving device sends to the transmitting device.
data.incorrect_answers__003: It prevents route tables from becoming outdated by decreasing the convergence time on a network.
data.explanation:
It prevents route tables from becoming outdated by decreasing the convergence time on a network.
The Spanning Tree Protocol is a long-standing protocol that runs in the background of bridged and switched networks to keep message loops from occurring.
data.incorrect_answers: ['It doesn't prevent any problem. Instead, it creates an overall routing table (a span tree) for the entire network.','It prevents buffer overflows by defining source-quench messages that a receiving device sends to the transmitting device.','It prevents route tables from becoming outdated by decreasing the convergence time on a network.']
data.answer1: It prevents message loops from developing when a switch or bridge is connected to the same location more than once.
data.answer2: It doesn't prevent any problem. Instead, it creates an overall routing table (a span tree) for the entire network.
data.answer3: It prevents buffer overflows by defining source-quench messages that a receiving device sends to the transmitting device.
data.answer4: It prevents route tables from becoming outdated by decreasing the convergence time on a network.

data.question:
You are configuring two Catalyst 2960 switches with redundant connections. To reduce spanning tree convergence times, you should configure the switches to actively negotiate an EtherChannel using LACP channel group 4.
Which command would you use for each redundant link?
data.correct_answer: Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode active
data.incorrect_answers__001: Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode desirable
data.explanation:
The channel-group 4 mode active command configures the interface to actively negotiate an EtherChannel by sending LACP packets for channel group 4. A channel is formed with another port group in either the active or passive mode.
The channel-group 4 mode passive command configures the interface into a passive negotiating state and forms an EtherChannel if the port receives LACP packets. While in this mode, the port does not initiate the negotiation.
The channel-group 4 mode desirable command configures the interface to actively negotiate the EtherChannel with PAgP. A channel is formed with another port group in either the auto or desirable mode.
The channel-group 4 mode auto command configures the interface in a passive negotiating state and forms an EtherChannel if the port receives PAgP packets. While in this mode, the port does not initiate the negotiation. This is the default EtherChannel mode.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode desirable','Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode auto','Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode passive']
data.answer1: Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode active
data.answer2: Switch(config-if)#channel-group 4 mode desirable

data.question:
You are verifying the configuration of spanning tree on a switch. You run the show spanning-tree command on switch A and see the following output.
VLAN0001
Spanning tree enabled protocol ieee
Root ID Priority 32768
Address 000e.8411.68c0
Cost 19
Port 26 (GigabitEthernet0/2)
Hello Time 2 sec Max Age 20 sec Forward Delay 15 sec
Bridge ID Priority 32769 (priority 32768 sys-id-ext 1)
Address 0030.1940.8b80

Hello Time 2 sec Max Age 20 sec Forward Delay 15 sec
Aging Time 300
Why isn't this switch the root bridge?
Interface Role Sts Cost Prio.Nbr Type
------------ ---- --- --------- -------- -------------------
Fa0/5 Altn BLK 19 128.5 P2p
Gi0/1 Desg FWD 19 128.25 P2p
Gi0/2 Root FWD 19 128.26 P2p
data.correct_answer: The VLAN number has been added to the configured bridge priority.
data.incorrect_answers__001: The MAC address for the root bridge is lower than that for switch A.
data.incorrect_answers__002: The link cost assigned to Gi0/2 is higher than the link cost assigned at the root bridge.
data.incorrect_answers__003: It has been configured with a higher priority value than the root bridge priority.
data.explanation:
Switch A is not the root bridge because its priority number is greater than the priority value of the root bridge. However, switch A has been configured with the same priority value (32768), but the VLAN number has been added to the priority value, giving it a priority of 32769.
You cannot configure a priority value of 32769, the priority value must be a multiple of 4096. The priority value of the switch is used first to determine the root bridge, with the switch with the lowest priority value being the root bridge. If the priority value matches, then the switch with the lowest MAC address becomes the root bridge. In this example, switch A has the lowest MAC address, but not the lowest total priority value after the VLAN number had been added.
Link costs are not used to determine the root bridge.
data.incorrect_answers: ['The MAC address for the root bridge is lower than that for switch A.','The link cost assigned to Gi0/2 is higher than the link cost assigned at the root bridge.','It has been configured with a higher priority value than the root bridge priority.']
data.answer1: The VLAN number has been added to the configured bridge priority.
data.answer2: The MAC address for the root bridge is lower than that for switch A.
data.answer3: The link cost assigned to Gi0/2 is higher than the link cost assigned at the root bridge.
data.answer4: It has been configured with a higher priority value than the root bridge priority.

data.question:
You have a small network as shown in the image.
Wrk1 is unable to communicate with Wrk2. Wrk1 can ping the router and all Internet hosts. Wrk2 can ping Wrk3.
What is the most likely cause of the problem?
data.correct_answer: Wrk1 and Wrk2 are on separate VLANs.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Wrk2 has an incorrect default gateway address configured.
data.incorrect_answers__002: An access list on the switch prevents communications between Wrk1 and Wrk2.
data.incorrect_answers__003: The cable connecting Wrk2 to Fa0/2 is bad.
data.explanation:
The most likely cause is that Wrk1 and Wrk2 are on separate VLANs. Ports that are assigned to different VLANs cannot communicate unless interVLAN routing has been configured. In this example, you will need to configure interVLAN routing on RouterA.
Because a ping from Wrk2 to Wrk3 works, you know that Wrk2 has a valid connection to the switch, which means the cable is good and port security is allowing Wrk2 to connect to the switch. A ping from Wrk1 to Wrk2 would not require a default gateway setting on either device. You configure access lists on a router, not on a switch. An access list filters based on IP address (Layer 3 information).
data.incorrect_answers: ['Wrk2 has an incorrect default gateway address configured.','An access list on the switch prevents communications between Wrk1 and Wrk2.','The cable connecting Wrk2 to Fa0/2 is bad.']
data.answer1: Wrk1 and Wrk2 are on separate VLANs.
data.answer2: Wrk2 has an incorrect default gateway address configured.
data.answer3: An access list on the switch prevents communications between Wrk1 and Wrk2.
data.answer4: The cable connecting Wrk2 to Fa0/2 is bad.

data.question: Which of the following is true of Multiprotocol Label Switching? (Select two.)
data.correct_answer: MPLS can carry ATM, SONET, and Ethernet traffic. And CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers.
data.incorrect_answers__001: CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers. And MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information.
data.incorrect_answers__002: MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information. And Packets routed using MPLS require additional routing lookup overhead.
data.incorrect_answers__003: Packets routed using MPLS require additional routing lookup overhead. And MPLS is designed to forward only packets created with the TCP/IP protocol.
data.explanation:
Key facts about Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) include the following:
  • MPLS can carry ATM, SONET, and Ethernet traffic.
  • CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers.
  • Packets are routed with a minimal amount of routing lookup overhead.
  • MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the label information, not on the packet contents.
  • MPLS is designed to support forwarding of protocols other than TCP/IP.
data.incorrect_answers: ['CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers. And MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information.','MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information. And Packets routed using MPLS require additional routing lookup overhead.','Packets routed using MPLS require additional routing lookup overhead. And MPLS is designed to forward only packets created with the TCP/IP protocol.',' ']
data.answer1: MPLS can carry ATM, SONET, and Ethernet traffic. And CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers.
data.answer2: CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers. And MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information.
data.answer3: MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information. And Packets routed using MPLS require additional routing lookup overhead.
data.answer4: Packets routed using MPLS require additional routing lookup overhead. And MPLS is designed to forward only packets created with the TCP/IP protocol.
data.all_answers: 'MPLS can carry ATM, SONET, and Ethernet traffic. And CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers.',CEF is required for all MPLS-enabled Cisco routers. And MPLS-enabled routers switch packets based on the packet contents, not on label information.'

data.question: Which is the default Layer 2 encapsulation method for serial interfaces on a Cisco router?
data.correct_answer: HDLC

data.explanation:
The High-Level Data Link Control (HDLC) WAN protocol is the default encapsulation method configured on Cisco serial interfaces.
Point-to-Point (PPP) and Frame Relay are two other common WAN encapsulation methods used on synchronous serial connections, but neither of them are the default. Ethernet is a LAN protocol and cannot be configured on serial interfaces.

IPsec employs ISAKMP for encryption key management.

data.question: What are DRs and BDRs used for when using the OSPF routing protocol?
data.correct_answer:
What are DRs and BDRs used for when using the OSPF routing protocol?
Correct Answer:
Reduce routing table updates in a broadcast type network.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Ensure a loopfree path between two networks.
data.incorrect_answers__002: Reduce routing table updates in a point-to-point type network.
data.incorrect_answers__003: Identify preferred and backup routes to improve recovery from link failure.
data.explanation:
OSPF uses designated routers (DR) and backup designated routers (BDR) on broadcast type networks (such as Ethernet) where multiple routers are on the same subnet to reduce the amount of traffic from routing table updates. Routing updates are sent to the DR, with the DR being responsible for propagating changes to other routers on the subnet.
On a point-to-point network, the DR and BDRs are not used, instead, routers begin exchanging routing information immediately following neighbor discovery. OSPF uses areas to organize the network into a hierarchical design. By design, OSPF is a link-state routing method, which includes built-in mechanisms for eliminating routing loops. Preferred and backup routes are characteristics of successor and feasible successor routes in EIGRP.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Ensure a loopfree path between two networks.','Reduce routing table updates in a point-to-point type network.','Identify preferred and backup routes to improve recovery from link failure.','Divide the network into a hierarchical configuration.']

What are DRs and BDRs used for when using the OSPF routing protocol?

Reduce routing table updates in a broadcast type network.
data.answer2: Ensure a loopfree path between two networks.
data.answer3: Reduce routing table updates in a point-to-point type network.
data.answer4: Identify preferred and backup routes to improve recovery from link failure.
data.answer5: Divide the network into a hierarchical configuration.

'What are DRs and BDRs used for when using the OSPF routing protocol?

data.question:
You are running OSPF as your routing protocol. One Ethernet subnet has five OSPF routers on the subnet. A partial configuration for two of the routers is shown below. Both routers are connected to the subnet through the Fa0/1 interface. All interfaces are up.

hostname RouterA	hostname RouterB
!	!
interface loopback0	interface FastEthernet0/0
 ip address 199.1.1.1 255.255.255.255	 ip address 172.18.1.12 255.255.255.192
!	!
interface FastEthernet0/0	interface FastEthernet0/1
 ip address 172.17.1.41 255.255.255.192	 ip address 172.16.1.200 255.255.255.128
!	!
interface FastEthernet0/1	router ospf 300
 ip address 172.16.1.250 255.255.255.128	 network 172.16.1.128 0.0.0.127 area 0
!	 network 172.18.1.0 0.0.0.63 area 0
router ospf 200	!
 network 172.16.1.128 0.0.0.127 area 0	--additional output omitted
 network 172.17.1.0 0.0.0.63 area 0
!
--additional output omitted
Assuming that either RouterA or RouterB will become the DR, which one will be elected the DR for the subnet?
data.correct_answer: RouterA will be the DR because of the loopback interface IP address.
data.incorrect_answers__001: RouterB will be the DR because of the Fa0/0 interface IP address.
data.incorrect_answers__002:
RouterB will be the DR because of the Fa0/0 interface IP address.
RouterA will be the DR because of the Fa0/1 interface IP address.
data.incorrect_answers__003: Router B will be the DR because of the OSPF process number.
data.explanation:
In this scenario, RouterA will be the DR because the IP address assigned to the loopback address is higher than any IP address assigned to RouterB. When choosing a DR, routers use the following process:
The router with the highest OSPF priority set on the interface becomes the DR.
If the priority value is not set, it defaults to 1, meaning all routers have the same priority. In this case, the highest router ID is used. The router ID for a router might come from three sources (used in this order):
The router ID configured for the OSPF process.
The highest IP address assigned to all loopback interfaces.
The highest IP address assigned to any remaining interface that is up.
In this example, both routers have the same priority, so the router ID is used.
Neither router has a router ID configured for the OSPF process.
RouterA has a loopback interface, so this becomes its router ID (199.1.1.1).
RouterB does not have a loopback interface, so the highest IP address for any of its up interfaces becomes its router ID (172.18.1.12).

data.answer2: RouterB will be the DR because of the Fa0/0 interface IP address.

RouterB will be the DR because of the Fa0/0 interface IP address.
RouterA will be the DR because of the Fa0/1 interface IP address.

data.correct_answer: They must be configured with matching areas. and They must have a shared data link.
data.incorrect_answers__001: They must be configured with matching OSPF process IDs. and Each serial interface must be configured to use a different subnet address.

data.explanation:
For routers to become neighbors using the OSPF routing protocol, they must:
Have a shared data link.
Have matching basic OSPF settings, including the OSPF area.
Maintain an exchange of hello packets.
However, the OSPF process IDs do not have to match between routers; the process ID is only used locally. Each router must be configured with a unique router ID. To establish connectivity, both interfaces on opposite ends of the data link must be configured with unique IP addresses that are both on the same subnet.

data.question: You are configuring OSPF for Area 0. SubnetA uses an address of 172.16.20.48/28. Which wildcard mask value would you use for the network statement?
data.explanation: Use 0.0.0.15 for the wildcard mask. To get the wildcard mask value, subtract the subnet mask value for each octet from 255. A 28-bit mask is 255.255.255.240, which translates into 0.0.0.15 (255-255 = 0, and 255-240 = 15).

data.question: You want to configure OSPF to run only on the interface with an IP address of 10.1.1.112/26 and you want to associate the interface with Area 3. Which of the following commands will accomplish your goal?
data.explanation:
The correct command is network 10.1.1.64 0.0.0.63 area 3. Address 10.1.1.112/26 is on subnet 10.1.1.64. The subnet mask is 255.255.255.192. The wildcard mask to use is 0.0.0.63 (255 - 192 = 63).
You can use the IP address instead of the subnet address in a network statement, but the wildcard mask would be 0.0.0.0.

data.question: You want to prevent all interfaces on a router from sending or responding to OSPF Hello messages. Which command should you use?
data.correct_answer: passive-interface default
data.incorrect_answers__001: no passive interface <type> <number>
data.incorrect_answers__003:
ipv6 unicast-routing
clear ipv6 ospf process
data.explanation:
The passive-interface default command configures all OSPF interfaces on the router as a passive interfaces. In this configuration, the router:
Does not send Hello messages on any interface.
Ignores Hello messages received from other routers on any interface.
The no passive interface command configures a single OSPF interface on the router as a non-passive interface. The ipv6 unicast-routing command enables the forwarding of IPv6 unicast packets. The clear ipv6 ospf process command clears the OSPF database, has it repopulated, and then performs the shortest path first (SPF) algorithm.

data.question: Contains LSAs and lists all possible routes
data.correct_answer: Topology
data.incorrect_answers__001: Adjacency
data.explanation:
OSPF has three databases:
The adjacency database, also known as the neighbor relationship table, lists all the neighbors that the router has learned about from hello packets.
The topology database contains LSAs and lists all possible routes. The topology database is built from the information gathered in the adjacency database.
The routing table database lists the best possible route calculated from the SPF (Shortest Path First) algorithm using information in the topology database.

data.question: Which of the following are benefits of EIGRP? (Select two.)
data.correct_answer: Supports manual route summarization  and  Rapid convergence
data.incorrect_answers__001: Rapid convergence and Operates within a controlled hierarchy
data.incorrect_answers__002: Operates within a controlled hierarchy  and Uses an open standard
data.incorrect_answers__003: Uses an open standard  and  Rapid convergence
data.explanation:
The major characteristics of EIGRP include:
Rapid convergence times for changes in the network topology. In some cases, convergence can be almost instantaneous because an EIGRP router stores backup routes for destinations. If no appropriate route or backup exists in the routing table, EIGRP will query neighbor routers to discover an alternate route. In this manner, EIGRP can quickly adapt to alternate routes when changes occur.
Automatic classful route summarization at major network boundaries is the default in EIGRP. Unlike IGRP and RIP, manual route summarization can also be configured on arbitrary network boundaries to reduce the routing table size.
Low use of network resources. During normal operation EIGRP transmits only hello packets across the network. EIGRP does not send periodic routing updates like RIP and IGRP. When change occurs, only routing table changes are propagated in EIGRP not the entire table. This minimizes bandwidth usage.
Multiple protocol support. EIGRP can exchange routes for IP, AppleTalk and IPX/SPX networks.
OSPF, not EIGRP is an open standard, operates within a controlled hierarchy, performs automatic classless route summarization, and uses areas.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Rapid convergence and Operates within a controlled hierarchy','Operates within a controlled hierarchy  and Uses an open standard','Uses an open standard  and  Rapid convergence',' ']
data.answer1: Supports manual route summarization  and  Rapid convergence
data.answer2: Rapid convergence and Operates within a controlled hierarchy
data.answer3: Operates within a controlled hierarchy  and Uses an open standard
data.answer4: Uses an open standard  and  Rapid convergence
data.all_answers: 'Supports manual route summarization  and  Rapid convergence',Rapid convergence and Operates within a controlled hierarchy',Operates within a controlled hierarchy  and Uses an open standard',Uses an open standard  and  Rapid convergence', ', ',&

data.question: You are currently using OSPF on your network. Which of the following would you gain by switching to EIGRP? (Select three.)
data.correct_answer: Multiprotocol support, Autosummarization, Faster recovery from primary link failure
data.incorrect_answers__001: Open standard, Hierarchical design using areas, Autosummarization
data.incorrect_answers__002:
Open standard, Hierarchical design using areas, Autosummarization
Hierarchical design using areas, Autosummarization, Equal-cost load balancing
data.incorrect_answers__003: Open standard, Equal-cost load balancing, Hierarchical design using areas
data.explanation:
EIGRP has the following benefits:
EIGRP supports autosummarization. OSPF only supports manual summarization between areas.
EIGRP uses feasible successors to identify backup routes that can be used. When the successor (the currently-used route) goes down, the feasible successor can be used immediately without recomputing routes. This provides fast recovery in the event of a link failure.
EIGRP supports multiple protocols, including IP, IPX, and AppleTalk.
EIGRP supports equal- and unequal-cost load balancing. OSPF supports equal-cost load balancing.
EIGRP is a Cisco-proprietary protocol. OSPF is an open standard protocol.
EIGRP lets you use a flexible design in your network. OSPF requires a hierarchical design using areas.
data.incorrect_answers:
['Open standard, Hierarchical design using areas, Autosummarization','Open standard, Hierarchical design using areas, Autosummarization

data.question: Which of the following describes the purpose of the exterior Border Gateway Protocol (eBGP)?
data.correct_answer: It is used when organizations need to share routing information across organizations and to advertise their block of public IP addresses to the world through their ISP.
data.incorrect_answers__001: It is used for creating a routing table based on a hybrid distance vector and link state routing algorithms.
data.incorrect_answers__002: It is used for creating a routing table based on exterior border routing algorithms.
data.incorrect_answers__003:
It is used by organizations when they need to share routing information across organizations and advertise their block of public IP addresses based on link state routing algorithms.
It is used for creating a routing table based on exterior border routing algorithms.
data.explanation:
Exterior border gateway protocol is used to share routing information across organizations and is used when organizations need to advertise their block of public IP addresses through their ISP to the world.
Unlike other protocols, eBGP selects a path to a destination based on the the path that involves the smallest number of autonomous systems. Further, the path selection algorithm uses path attributes instead of a single metric.

data.question:
You are reviewing the configuration of a router that uses EIGRP for its routing protocol. Shown below is the output from the show ip eigrp topology all-links command:
Router# show ip eigrp topology all-links
IP-EIGRP Topology Table for process 77
Codes: P - Passive, A - Active, U - Update, Q - Query, R - Reply, r - Reply status
P 172.16.90.0 255.255.255.0, 2 successors, FD is 46251776
via 172.16.80.28 (46251776/46226176), Ethernet0
via 172.16.81.28 (46251776/46226176), Ethernet1
via 172.16.80.31 (46277376/46251889), Serial0
P 172.16.81.0 255.255.255.0, 1 successors, FD is 307200
via 172.16.82.28 (307200/281600), Ethernet1
via 172.16.80.28 (308500/281600), Ethernet0
via 172.16.80.31 (332800/307900), Serial0
Based on the output, which of the following is true for the route to network 172.16.81.0/24?
data.correct_answer: The route through Ethernet1 is the successor route.
data.incorrect_answers__001: Variance has been configured with a value greater than 1.
data.incorrect_answers__002: If the successor routes to the network are lost, the route through Ethernet1 will automatically take its place.
data.incorrect_answers__003: The route through Serial0 is a feasible successor route.
data.explanation:
Network 172.16.81.0/24 has a single successor route as indicated by the 1 successors entry. Successor routes are the top n routes in the following list. In this example, because there is a single successor route, the first route (through Ethernet1) is the successor route. Network 172.16.90.0/24 has 2 successor routes; the routes through Ethernet0 and Ethernet1.
Network 172.16.81.0/24 has one additional route that is a feasible successor route (through Ethernet0). To qualify as a feasible successor, the route's advertised distance (AD) must be lower than the feasible distance for the network. The feasible distance is indicated by the FD is 307200 entry. The AD is the second value listed for the route cost. For Ethernet0, the AD is 281600. The route through Serial0 is not a feasible successor because it's AD (307900) is higher than the FD for the network.
A route that does not qualify for a feasible successor route might indicate a route with a loop, but it does not guarantee that a loop exists.
If variance had been configured to a value greater than 1, the network would have had 2 successor routes (the route through Ethernet0 would have been a successor route).

data.answer2: Variance has been configured with a value greater than 1.
data.answer3: If the successor routes to the network are lost, the route through Ethernet1 will automatically take its place.
data.answer4: The route through Serial0 is a feasible successor route.
data.answer5: The route through Serial0 indicates a route with a loop.

data.question: Which of the following IS NOT A component of a link-state routing protocol?
data.correct_answer: Periodic routing table exchanges
data.incorrect_answers__001: Topological database
data.explanation:
Link-state routing protocols use hello packets to discover neighboring routers. They then exchange Link-state Advertisements (LSAs) to construct a topological database. An SPF (shortest path first) algorithm is applied to the topological database to form a tree representing the relative layout of the network. The SPF tree is then used to build a table of routing paths and associated ports.
Periodic routing table exchanges, hop and tick counts, poison reverse, and split horizon loop avoidance are all components of distance vector routing protocols.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Topological database','SPF algorithm','LSA packets']
data.answer1: Periodic routing table exchanges
data.answer2: Topological database

data.question:
You need to implement a WAN solution for a small business located in a remote mountain location. Currently, the local telecom only offers basic phone service at the location. Leased lines are not available.
Which option would be the most appropriate choice?
data.correct_answer: VSAT satellite link
data.incorrect_answers__001: POTS with a modem
data.explanation:
In locations where wired WAN service isn't available due to location or physical geography, a satellite-based WAN connection can be established using Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT) satellite links. VSAT uses satellite dishes, radio signals, and satellites to provide wireless WAN connectivity.
A dial-up POTS WAN connection could be used in this scenario. However, the data transfer speeds would be unacceptably slow. ATM and Frame Relay require the telecom to provide a wired WAN infrastructure, which isn't available in this scenario.
data.incorrect_answers: ['POTS with a modem','Frame Relay','ATM']
data.answer1: VSAT satellite link
data.answer2: POTS with a modem

data.question: When implementing a Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) WAN, what data unit is managed by the routers at different sites?
data.correct_answer: Packets
data.incorrect_answers__001: Frames
data.explanation:
In a Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) WAN, IP packets are forwarded between sites. Packets are forwarded based on the contents of the label, without examination of the packet. This allows the creation of end-to-end circuits across any type of WAN transport medium, using any protocol.
Bits are delivered with leased line WANs. Frames are delivered with Frame Relay and Ethernet WAN implementations.
data.incorrect_answers:
['Frames','Bits','Bits
Datagrams']
data.answer1: Packets
data.answer2: Frames

data.question: Which of the following is not a VPN tunnel protocol?
data.correct_answer: RADIUS
data.incorrect_answers__001: PPTP
data.explanation:
RADIUS is a centralized remote access authentication service. However, RADIUS can be deployed to handle authentication for clients connecting via VPNs.
L2TP, PPTP, and IPsec are all VPN tunnel protocols.
data.incorrect_answers: ['PPTP','Ipsec','L2TP']
data.answer1: RADIUS
data.answer2: PPTP

data.question: Which IPsec subprotocol provides data encryption?
data.correct_answer: Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP)
data.incorrect_answers__001: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
data.explanation:
The Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) protocol provides data encryption for IPsec traffic.
The Authentication Header (AH) provides message integrity through authentication, verifying that data are received unaltered from the trusted destination. Because AH provides no privacy, it is often combined with ESP to achieve integrity and confidentiality.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)','Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)','Authentication Header (AH)']
data.answer1: Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP)
data.answer2: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)

data.question: Which of the following are benefits of EIGRP?
data.correct_answer: Low use of network resources AND Supports multiple protocols
data.incorrect_answers__001:
Supports multiple protocols AND Operates within a controlled hierarchy
Low use of network resources AND Supports multiple protocols
data.incorrect_answers__002: Uses an open standard AND Supports multiple protocols
data.incorrect_answers__003: Operates within a controlled hierarchy AND Supports multiple protocols
data.explanation:
The major characteristics of EIGRP include:
• Rapid convergence times for changes in the network topology. In some cases, convergence can be almost instantaneous because an EIGRP router stores backup routes for destinations. If no appropriate route or backup exists in the routing table, EIGRP will query neighbor routers to discover an alternate route. In this manner, EIGRP can quickly adapt to alternate routes when changes occur.
• Low use of network resources. During normal operation EIGRP transmits only hello packets across the network. EIGRP does not send periodic routing updates like RIP and IGRP. When change occurs, only routing table changes are propagated in EIGRP not the entire table. This minimizes bandwidth usage.
• Automatic classful route summarization at major network boundaries is the default in EIGRP. Unlike IGRP and RIP, manual route summarization can also be configured on arbitrary network boundaries to reduce the routing table size.
• Multiple protocol support. EIGRP can exchange routes for IP, AppleTalk and IPX/SPX networks.
OSPF, not EIGRP, is an open standard that operates within a controlled hierarchy, performs automatic classless route summarization, and uses areas.
data.incorrect_answers:
['Supports multiple protocols AND Operates within a controlled hierarchy
Low use of network resources AND Supports multiple protocols','Uses an open standard AND Supports multiple protocols','Operates within a controlled hierarchy AND Supports multiple protocols']
data.answer1: Low use of network resources AND Supports multiple protocols
data.answer2:
Supports multiple protocols AND Operates within a controlled hierarchy
Low use of network resources AND Supports multiple protocols
data.answer3: Uses an open standard AND Supports multiple protocols
data.answer4: Operates within a controlled hierarchy AND Supports multiple protocols

data.question:
Which IPv6 ACL types match with these descriptions of their usage:
Filters traffic on Layer 2 interfaces
Applies to all packets
Filters inbound traffic
data.correct_answer: Port ACL
data.incorrect_answers__001: Router ACL
data.explanation:
The two types of IPv6 ACLs are used as follows:
• Router ACLs filter inbound and outbound traffic on Layer 3 interfaces (e.g., routed ports, SVIs, etc.). Router ACLs are applied only to packets that are routed.
Port ACLs filter inbound traffic on Layer 2 interfaces. Port ACLs are applied to all packets, therefore taking precedence.
data.incorrect_answers: ['Router ACL',' ',' ']
data.answer1: Port ACL
data.answer2: Router ACL
